Esprima

Esprima is a tool to perform

Lexical analysis

Syntactical analysis

Using Node.js to play with Esprima

$ npm install esprima

example

 $ node
> var esprima = require('esprima')
undefined
> esprima.parseScript('answer = 42')
Script {
  type: 'Program',
  body: [ ExpressionStatement { type: 'ExpressionStatement', expression: [Object] } ],
  sourceType: 'script' }

Syntactic Analysis

The main use case of Esprima is to parse a JavaScript program. This is also known as syntactic analysis. 
 
	
		
esprima.parseScript(input, config, delegate)
	
esprima.parseModule(input, config, delegate)

Distinguishing

Script

 $ node
> var esprima = require('esprima')
> esprima.parseScript('answer = 42');
Script {
  type: 'Program',
  body: [ ExpressionStatement { type: 'ExpressionStatement', expression: [Object] } ],
  sourceType: 'script' }

Module 

 $ node
> var esprima = require('esprima')
> esprima.parseModule('import { sqrt } from "math.js"');
Module {
  type: 'Program',
  body:
   [ ImportDeclaration {
       type: 'ImportDeclaration',
       specifiers: [Object],
       source: [Object] } ],
  sourceType: 'module' }

Tolerant Mode

Tolerant: false 

 $ node > var esprima = require('esprima') > esprima.parseScript('"use strict"; with (x) {}') 
 Error: Line 1: Strict mode code may not include a with statement

Tolerant: true 

 $ node
> var esprima = require('esprima')
> esprima.parseScript('"use strict"; with (x) {}', { tolerant: true })
Script {
  type: 'Program',
  body:
   [ Directive {
       type: 'ExpressionStatement',
       expression: [Object],
       directive: 'use strict' },
     WithStatement { type: 'WithStatement', object: [Object], body: [Object] } ],
  sourceType: 'script',
  errors:
   [ { Error: Line 1: Strict mode code may not include a with statement
       index: 13,
       lineNumber: 1,
       description: 'Strict mode code may not include a with statement' } ] }

Lexical Analysis (Tokenization)

Esprima tokenizer takes a string as an input and produces an array of tokens, a list of object representing categorized input characters. This is known asÂ lexical analysis. 

 esprima.tokenize(input, config)

example

 $ node 
> var esprima = require('esprima') 
esprima.tokenize('answer = 42') 

[ { type: 'Identifier', value: 'answer' },     { type: 'Punctuator', value: '=' },
{ type: 'Numeric', value: '42' } ]

Differences

Syntactical analysis

Esprima parser fully understands JSX syntax when jsx flag in the parsing configuration object is set to true

The parse function can not work with an input string

Lexical analysis

Esprima tokenizer is unable to process input source that contains a mix of JavaScript code and JSX.

The tokenize function can work with an input string that does not represent a valid JavaScript program

Limitation on Keywords

Syntactical analysis 

 $ node 
var esprima = require('esprima') >
 esprima.parseScript('x.if = 1').body[0].expression.left.property 
Identifier { type: 'Identifier', name: 'if' }

Lexical analysis 

 $ node 
> var esprima = require('esprima')
esprima.tokenize('x.if = 1')
 [
{ type: 'Identifier', value: 'x' },
{ type: 'Punctuator', value: '.' },
{ type: 'Keyword', value: 'if' },
{ type: 'Punctuator', value: '=' }, 
{ type: 'Numeric', value: '1' } 
]

Thank you for your attention !
